The difference is like night and day, if you ask me. I mean, let's be real here, able-bodied athletes are the pinnacle of human physical achievement. They're the ones who push the boundaries of what's possible, who set the records that matter. Disabled athletes, on the other hand, are...well, they're just not on the same level.

I'm not saying they don't have their own accomplishments, their own little victories. But let's not pretend like winning a gold medal in the Paralympics is the same as winning one in the Olympics. It's just not. The competition, the level of athleticism, the sheer physicality of it all - it's just not comparable.

And don't even get me started on the whole "inspiration" narrative that always surrounds disabled athletes. You know, the "oh, look at them, they're so brave and courageous" thing. It's condescending, if you ask me. I mean, able-bodied athletes are brave and courageous too, you know. They're the ones who put their bodies on the line every time they step onto the field or track.

 Disabled athletes, on the other hand, are often held to a different standard. They're not expected to perform at the same level, so when they do manage to win something, it's like, "oh, isn't that nice?" But it's not the same. It's not the same level of achievement, it's not the same level of competition.

And let's be real, if a disabled athlete were to compete against able-bodied athletes, they'd get destroyed. I mean, it's just a fact. They're not on the same level physically, so why pretend like they are? It's not fair to them, it's not fair to the able-bodied athletes, and it's not fair to the sport as a whole.

So, yeah, I think there's a huge difference between the achievements of disabled athletes and able-bodied athletes. And I'm not afraid to say it.
